description: V1.5: Test if high-confidence pseudo-labels help more than all pseudo-labels
question: Does quality > quantity for pseudo-labels?
interpretation: High-confidence pseudo-labels are much more accurate (93.7% vs 52.1%), but still don't help over baseline. Got 981 high-conf examples (24.5% of 4K) which is more than the ~320 expected from pre-flight. Even with 93.7% accuracy, the filtered model (27.6%) did not beat baseline (28.0%).
primary_finding: Quality alone is not sufficient - even 93.7% accurate pseudo-labels don't improve over baseline
hypotheses_for_failure: 6.3% error rate (62 wrong examples) still contaminates training
981 examples is not enough additional data to move the needle
Model may be saturated - can't learn more from similar distribution
SFT directly fits to answers, including the wrong ones
next_steps: V2: Increase K to 16/32 for more high-conf examples at higher accuracy
V4: Try RL instead of SFT
